awd_titl_txt: The Lineage and Clonal Relationships of the Primitive Blood
awd_abstract_narration:
The central aim of this project is to understand the lineage relationships between the blood cell types that arise in the early vertebrate embryo. In vertebrates, hematopoietic stem cells produce the adult blood, termed the definitive blood.  These stem cells produce complex lineages that develop into a complete array of adult blood histotypes. However, in the early embryo, the first blood  - the primitive blood - forms from simple lineages from cells termed hemangioblasts.  Illuminating the common elements in the emergence of these blood types will help in understanding the genetically encoded mechanisms that control blood cell development.  

The major approach of this project is to fluorescently label cells, follow them in a live embryo (the zebrafish) using time lapse microscopy and later to identify the progeny of the labeled cells using gene expression studies.  This project will first establish the lineage relationships between the major blood divisions, the primitive and definitive lineages, and between major subdivisions, such as erythroid and myeloid lineages.  The project will also establish when and where developmental restrictions occur in the blood lineage.  By collecting all the divisions of the clones in a living embryo, this project will set a major milestone in the understanding of hematopoiesis: the construction of the first in vivo blood lineage in any creature.

A better understanding of the emergence of cells in the hematopoietic system will ultimately lead to the ability to better understand blood-specific stem cells in general and help in the derivation of hematopoietic stem cells from in vitro-derived embryonic sources.  This project will fund the training of both undergraduate and graduate students in developmental biology and genetics; these research findings, including images and time-lapse movies, will be made available over the internet for research and instructional uses.

In vertebrates, there is an early population of blood cells in the embryo that are necessary for early respiration; later in development this early population is replaced with more adult like blood cells. Understanding how these different blood cell types are determined in the developing embryo is thought to be essential for understanding the initial steps in blood replacement therapy, which has great potential in the treatment of blood diseases and cancers.

The early blood (called primitive blood) is generated by individual blood progenitors; these progenitors are not thought to share lineage with the later blood (called definitive blood). We proposed to determine using lineage analysis if decisions between primitive and definitive blood occur in the early embryo in the first cell cycles after the completion of gastrulation. One of our strategies was to ask what happened to blood cell fate when cells did not divide, using mutants in which early cell division is normal but later cell division is arrested. Cells in the cycle mutant harpy bypass mitosis and do not divide; cells in the cycle mutant zombie arrest in mitosis during gastrulation. Both harpy and zombie mutants have primitive blood cells, but only harpy has additional definitive blood cells. In clonal analysis, we found that clones of cells in harpy mutants contain only one blood cell and this cell is either a primitive cell type or a definitive cell type. This suggests that definitive blood may be derived from a dividing population of stem-like progenitor cells, and these cells are lost in zombie mutants.

It is known that pronephros, blood and endothelium arise from the same region of the embryo (termed intermediate mesoderm). Again, we used clonal analysis in wild type and harpy mutant embryos to assess the lineage relationships between these three tissues. First, it is thought that blood lineages pass through an obligate asymmetric division of a cell termed a hemangioblast where one daughter gives rise to endothelial cells (cells that line the blood vessels) and the other gives rise to blood cells. In our clonal analysis of harpy mutants, we found that usually there was only one blood cell or one endothelial cell in a clone. This observation does not support the hypothesis of an obligate hemangioblast in blood lineages. Second, we found that in wild type embryos blood+endothelium or pronephros+endothelium commonly derive from the same clone, however blood+pronephros normally never derive from the same clone unless endothelial cells are also present in the lineage. In harpy mutants, we found that blood and pronephros were often together in the same clone, regardless of whether the blood cell was primitive or definitive; furthermore, these clones never included endothelial cells. These results demonstrate that the earliest hierarchical fate distinction occurs between a pronephric fate versus a blood+endothelial fate and this happens sometime before the end of gastrulation. One possible interpretation of the harpy data is a bipotent progenitor exists that produces both blood and endothelium, however because it cannot divide defaults to one or the other fate. In support of this idea, endothelium and pronephros did often derive together from the same harpy clone (just never with blood).
